titleStmt.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of Ta-Nb-Zr-Ti-Al refractory high entropy alloys with varying Ta/Ti ratios

analytic.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of Ta-Nb-Zr-Ti-Al refractory high entropy alloys with varying Ta/Ti ratios

biblStruct.note: Received: 30 March 2021 / Revised: 6 June 2021 / Accepted: 6 June 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) containing disordered body-centered cubic (BCC) and ordered BCC (B2) structures often exhibit high strength but low ductility at room temperature, even in the compressive tests. In this study, (Ta 25-x Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25+x ) 95 Al 5 (x = 0, 5, 10) RHEAs are fabricated to investigate the compositional dependence of the microstructures and mechanical properties. All the three alloys exhibit a single BCC structure at the as-cast and solution-treated states, while the basket weave-like microstructures consisting of cuboidal and strip-like phases are formed after aging at 600 °C. The microstructure of the aged alloys is sensitive to the compositions: only disordered BCC1 + BCC2 dual phases are observed in the (Ta 25 Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25 ) 95 Al 5 alloy; additional B2 phases are formed by replacing 5 at% Ta with Ti; a complex microstructure containing BCC1 + BCC2 + B2 + Omega phases are identified in the (Ta 15 Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 35 ) 95 Al 5 alloy. Although replacing Ta with Ti results in a reduction of compressive yield strength from 1762 to 1243 MPa, the fracture strain is greatly enhanced from 7.3 to 44.3%, indicating that the strength-ductility balance can be tuned to a large extent in this RHEA system.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: High entropy alloys (HEAs) have attracted increasing research attention due to their outstanding mechanical properties [1][2][3][4][5][6][7] and unique physical properties [8,9]. Among this new family of alloys, refractory HEAs (RHEAs) have been considered as one of the promising candidates for future high-temperature structural materials, aiming at overcoming the service temperature limit of commercial Ni-based superalloys [10][11][12][13][14][15][16].

Extensive previous investigations have demonstrated that introducing secondary phases with coherent interfaces to the matrix is an important method to strengthen HEAs. For the HEAs with disordered face-centered cubic (FCC) structure, the ordered FCC (L1 2 ) precipitates in the Ni-Co-Fe-Cr-Ti-Al alloys enhance their strength without significant loss in ductility [17][18][19]. For the RHEAs with body-centered cubic (BCC) structure, most reported alloys containing disordered BCC and ordered BCC (B2) phases exhibit a basket-weave-like microstructure consisting of cuboidal, spherical, and/or strip-like morphologies [20][21][22][23], which is similar to some FCC-L1 2 dual-phases Ni-based superalloys [24][25][26], and usually brings them high strength. For example, the equiatomic AlNbTiZr alloy, consisting of a B2 matrix and Zr 5 Al 3 precipitates, has a compressive yield strength of 1579 MPa [27]. With the addition of Mo and Ta elements, the AlMo 0.5 NbTa 0.5 TiZr alloy is composed of continuous channels of B2 matrix and periodic cuboidal and plate-like BCC precipitates, achieving an ultrahigh yield strength of 2197 MPa but a low fracture strain of 4.7% [21]. The morphology and mechanical properties of such coherent BCC/B2-structured RHEAs can be modified via tuning the composition and annealing process. For example, reducing the Al concentration in this alloy may result in the spherical BCC-structured precipitates uniformly distributed in the B2 matrix, exhibiting a higher yield strength of 2350 MPa but lower fracture strain of 3.2% [21]. A special phase inversion, from the B2 matrix and cuboidal BCC precipitates to the BCC matrix with discrete B2 precipitates, can be observed in the Al 0.5 NbTa 0.8 Ti 1.5 V 0.2 Zr alloy after annealing at 600 °C for 120 h, which improves the fraction strain from 4.7% to 16.9% while keeping a high yield strength of over 1300 MPa [28,29]. Recently, a novel Al 0.4 Nb 0.5 Ta 0.5 TiZr 0.8 alloy containing cuboidal B2 precipitates in BCC matrix is designed with a compressive yield strength of 1232 MPa and a fracture strain of ~ 10% [30]. Overall speaking, although the BCC/B2 structured RHEAs have exhibited high yield strengths, their fracture strain (even in the compressive tests) has usually been low (< 10%) at room temperature, which strongly limits their potential practical applications.

A series of Ta 25-x Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25+x RHEAs have been designed to tune their Pugh's ratio and Poisson's ratio by the replacement of Ta with Ti, achieving a better strengthductility trade-off [31][32][33][34]. Furthermore, it has been reported that the addition of 5.88 at% Al in equiatomic TaNbZrTi alloy can cause the formation of BCC/B2 dual-phases [21], although high Al concentrations may deteriorate the ductility of RHEAs, as evidenced in HfNbZrTiAl x [35] and Al x Ti 50-x VNbMo [36]. Inspired by the previous alloy design strategies, in this study, 5 at% Al element is added into Ta-Nb-Zr-Ti alloys, i.e., (Ta 25-x Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25+x ) 95 Al 5 (x = 0, 5, 10). Their microstructures and mechanical properties are investigated, showing that the strength and ductility can be tuned to a large extent by controlling the Ta/Ti ratio and annealing treatments.

div.head: Experimental
div.p: The alloys with three designed compositions, (Ta 25-x Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25+x ) 95 Al 5 (x = 0, 5, 10), were fabricated, and are denoted in short as Ta 25 Ti 25 , Ta 20 Ti 30 , and Ta 15 Ti 35 in the following text, respectively. The Ta, Nb, Zr, Ti, and Al elemental metals with the purity of > 99.9% were used as raw materials, which were mixed by arc melting in the Ti-gettered high purity argon atmosphere. The as-cast ingots were flipped and re-melted at least six times with electromagnetic stirring, to enhance chemical homogeneity. The as-cast alloys were solution-treated (ST) at 1300 °C for 24 h, followed by water quenching, and denoted as ST-1300/24 in the following text. The alloys were then aged at 600 °C for 6, 12, and 24 h, which were depicted as 600-6, 600-12, and 600-24, respectively. During the heat treatment, all samples were wrapped in a Ta foil, and were sealed in the evacuated argon-backfilled quartz tubes.

The phases of the alloys were identified using X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker) with Cu Kα radiation in a 2θ range from 20° to 90°. The microstructures were characterized using a Zeiss Supra55 scanning electron microscope (SEM) coupled with backscatter electron (BSE) spectrometry. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations of the aged samples were performed with FEI Talos F200X microscopy operated at 200 kV with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), and the TEM samples were prepared using ion milling after mechanical grounding down to the thickness of 30 μm. Room temperature compression tests were performed using an Instron machine under a strain rate of 1 × 10 -3 s -1 , and the test specimens are in the shape of a cylinder (Φ4 × 6 mm).

div.head: Microstructure of the as-cast and solution-treated alloys
div.p: The XRD patterns of the as-cast Ta 25 Ti 25 , Ta 20 Ti 30 and Ta 15 Ti 35 alloys are shown in Fig. 1a. All the peaks can be indexed with a BCC structure. The lattice constants (a) are determined as: Ta 25 Ti 25 (a = 0.3344 ± 0.0001 nm), Ta 20 Ti 30 (a = 0.3353 ± 0.0002 nm), and Ta 15 Ti 35 (a = 0.3363 ± 0.0002 nm). The increment of lattice constants with decreasing Ta/Ti ratio may be ascribed to the larger atomic radius of Ti (0.146 nm) than Ta (0.143 nm) [31]. Figure 1b-d show the representative SEM-BSE images of the three as-cast alloys, in which the dendrite and interdendrite regions can be clearly identified due to constitutional segregation during solidification. The compositions determined with EDS analyses are listed in Table 1, according to which the dendrite regions are Nb-and Ta-enriched, due to their higher melting points, while the interdendrite regions are Zr-and Al-enriched. The distribution of Ti element seems to be relatively uniform in all the three as-cast alloys.

The XRD patterns and SEM-BSE images of the solutiontreated alloys are shown in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2a, all the XRD patterns exhibit a single BCC structure, with no peaks observed corresponding to secondary phases. The microstructures consist of equiaxed grains without notable dendrite features and secondary phases, as shown in Fig. 2b-d. The average grain size ranges from 130 to 542 μm with decreasing Ta/Ti ratio. The SEM-BSE images of the aged alloys are shown in Fig. 4. After aging for 6 h and 12 h, the three alloys exhibit similar basket-weave-like microstructures, and no secondary phase aggregation is observed at grain boundaries, as shown in Fig. 4a-f. This basket-weave-like morphology is similar to several RHEAs reported in literatures, such as AlMo 0.5 NbTa 0.5 TiZr [20] and Al 0.5 NbTa 0.8 Ti 1.5 V 0.2 Zr alloys [29], and may be induced from spinodal decomposition due to the miscibility gap between Ta and Zr, as well as the ordering processes related to the presence of Al [20][21][22][23]. The distinct secondary phase aggregation occurs after 24 h aging, especially when more Ta is replaced with Ti, as shown in Fig. 4g-i. Slight secondary phase aggregation around grain boundaries can be observed in the Ta 25 Ti 25 alloy; micron-scale secondary phase aggregation is formed inside the grains in the Ta 20 Ti 30 alloy; at least three phases, corresponding to the bright, grey, and dark regions, can be identified in the Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy.

div.head: Microstructure of the aged alloys
div.p: The detailed microstructural features of these aged alloys are characterized using TEM, as shown in Figs. 5 and6. For the Ta 25 Ti 25 alloy aged for 6 h, according to the high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) image and EDS results in Fig. 5a,c, the basket-weave-like microstructure is composed of bright cuboidal (Nb, Ta)-rich and dark strip-like (Al, Zr)-rich phases. The Ti element seems to be distributed uniformly in this alloy. Further atomicscaled HAADF image and the corresponding Fast Fourier Transforms (FFT) pattern, shown in Fig. 5b, suggest that both the bright and dark phases are BCC structured, but strong local disorder appears at the boundary regions, which may be attributed to clustering of Zr with the largest atomic radius (0.160 nm) among the constituent elements. Similar features have been observed in the equiatomic HfNbZrTa alloy due to the clustering of Hf and Zr elements [37]. Prolonged aging till 24 h does not change the basket-weave-like morphology, compositional distribution, and the average size of cuboidal phases (47 nm) in this alloy, as shown in Fig. 5d-f. The basket-weave-like microstructure and elemental distribution in the Ta 20 Ti 30 alloy after 24 h aging are similar to those observed in the Ta 25 Ti 25 alloy, as shown in Fig. 6a-c. However, the average size of cuboidal (Nb, Ta)rich phases in the Ta 20 Ti 30 alloy (85 nm) is larger than that in the Ta 25 Ti 25 alloy. More importantly, a strong superlattice reflection of B2 phases coherent with the BCC matrix can be clearly seen in the SAED pattern, as shown in Fig. 6b. In other words, replacing Ta with Ti seems to promote the B2 ordering with the same amount of Al addition.

With further replacement of Ta into Ti, the average size of the cuboidal phases rises to 103 nm, and the microstructure of Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy aged for 24 h consists of the cuboidal (Nb, Ta)-rich BCC, strip-like (Ti, Al, Zr)-rich B2, and discrete (Al, Zr)-rich Omega phases, as shown in Fig. 6d-f, consistent with the XRD result in Fig. 3c. It should be noted that, unlike the B2 phases, the Omega phases are poor in Ti element, which are marked in Fig. 6f with orange dashed circles. Besides those in the BCC-structured Ti alloys [38,39], the Omega phases are usually formed with the collapse of the {111} planes of B2 phases under annealing in the metastable B2-type Ti alloys [40,41]. The Omega phases have also been found in many BCC/B2-structured RHEAs, such as Al 10 Nb 15 Ta 5 Ti 30 Zr 40 [42] and Al 0.5 NbTa 0.8 Ti 1.5 V 0.2 Zr [43]. Overall speaking, replacing Ta with Ti will diminish the stability of the BCC structure in this alloy system.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: The compressive mechanical properties of the ST-1300/24 and 600-24 samples are shown in Fig. 7. The ST-1300/24 alloys exhibit good compressive ductility without fracture during loading. Their yield strength σ 0.2 is reduced from 1304, 1112, to 973 MPa with the substitution of Ta with Ti. After aging at 600 °C for 24 h, the yield strength is enhanced up to 1762, 1509, and 1243 MPa of the Ta 25 Ti 25 , Ta 20 Ti 30 , and Ta 15 Ti 35 alloys, respectively. As mentioned above, although high strengths are commonly seen in the RHEAs containing basket-weave-like BCC/B2 microstructures, most previous alloys exhibited very low compressive ductility (< 10%) [21,44]. Here, in contrast, the forming for B2 and Omega phases reduces the yield strength but greatly enhances the ductility ε, from 7.3% for Ta 25 Ti 25 , 21.6% for Ta 20 Ti 30 to 44.3% for Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy.

This unusual microstructural dependence on the mechanical properties may be attributed to the following factors. First, it has been reported that both the Pugh's ratio and Poisson's ratio increase with substitution of Ti for Ta in the Ta 25-x Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25+x base alloys, suggesting an enhanced ductility and stability of the solid against shear deformation [34]. Second, since the atomic size of Ti is larger than that of Ta, replacing Ta with Ti leads to slight reduction of atomic mismatch from 4.78% of Ta 25 Ti 25 alloy to 4.67% of Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy, calculated according to the atomic-size difference Delta [45] and the parameters in Ref. [31], and therefore caused a reduced solid solution strengthening. Moreover, although the content of each phase can hardly been quantified, the content of B2 phase in Ta 15 Ti 35 could be less than that in Ta 20 Ti 30 , since the Omega phases observed in Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy may be transformed from the B2 phases, which has been commonly observed in the metastable Ti alloys [40,41]. Furthermore, according to the TEM observations, the average size of cuboidal phases increases from 47 to 103 nm with decreasing Ta/Ti ratio, indicating lower density of interfaces to hinder the dislocation gliding, which may also result in better deformation capability. It needs to be noted that, although considerable compressive ductility has been achieved, the present alloys still hold near-zero tensile ductility according to our tensile tests. Recently, it has been proposed that RHEAs with a compressive ductility larger than 30% may also possess measureable tensile ductility [46]. However, our results show that the Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy with a compressive ductility over 44% fractures before yielding in the tensile tests, which may be due to complicated correlation between yield strength and ductility of multi-phases RHEAs. Therefore, further efforts are desired to improve the tensile properties of this series of RHEAs to broaden their application fields.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In the present study, the microstructures and mechanical properties of three RHEAs, (Ta 25-x Nb 25 Zr 25 Ti 25+x ) 95 Al 5 (x = 0, 5, 10), have been investigated at their as-cast, solution-treated, and aged states. At the solution-treated state, single-phase BCC structures with equiaxed grain microstructures are observed in all the three alloys, but the average grain size increases from 130 to 542 μm with decreasing Ta/Ti ratio. After aging at 600 °C for 6 h and 12 h, the three alloys exhibit a similar basket-weave-like microstructure. Extension of the aging time to 24 h results in considerable differences in the microstructures and mechanical properties between the three alloys: the average size of cuboidal phases increases from 47 to 103 nm with decreasing Ta/Ti ratio, while, more importantly, B2 and B2/Omega phases are formed when 5 and 10 at% of Ta is replaced with Ti, respectively. Although the mechanical properties are similar of these alloys at their solution-treated states, significant differences are observed after aging. The Ta 25 Ti 25 alloy exhibits the highest strength of 1762 MPa but very limited ductility below 10%; on the contrary, the Ta 20 Ti 30 and Ta 15 Ti 35 alloys exhibit lower yield strength (1509 and 1243 MPa, respectively) but much higher fracture strain, achieving over 40% for Ta 15 Ti 35 . These results demonstrate a large space to tune the strength and ductility in this RHEA system, which may broaden the scope of their potential application fields.

figure.head: Figure 3
figure.figDesc: Figure3shows the XRD patterns of the three alloys aged at 600 ℃ for different periods. After 6 h aging, the Ta 25 Ti 25 and Ta 20 Ti 30 alloys still exhibit a single BCC structure, while two sets of BCC peaks can be observed in the Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy. With increasing the aging time to 12 h, the peaks of secondary BCC phases can be observed in both the Ta 25 Ti 25 and Ta 20 Ti 30 alloys, while a B2 phase can be identified in the Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy. After 24 h aging, no further change is observed in the XRD patterns of the Ta 25 Ti 25 and Ta 20 Ti 30 alloys, while an Omega phase can be identified in the Ta 15 Ti 35 alloy.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 11905008).

Author contributions Ya-Guang Dong wrote the draft; Ya-Guang Dong, Shang Chen, Nan-Nan Jia, and Qiu-Hong Zhang collected the data; Liang Wang, Yun-Fei Xue, and Ke Jin contributed to conceive the idea of the study. All authors contributed to the writing the revisions.
